newsitem.title: INDONESIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - June 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - June 11.

text.p: The following are the leading stories in the Indonesian press on June 11. Reuters has not verified these stories and does notvouch for their accuracy.

Trade and Industry Minister Tunky Ariwibowo said Japan had asked for tax and tariff reductions during a new round of talks with Indonesia on its national car policy. Indonesia is currently holding talks with Japan, the United States and the European Union following complaints about the policy, which grants tax and tariff exemptions to PT Timor Putra Nasional, a company controlled by President Suharto's son Hutomo Mandala Putra.
A military investigation team has found the recent crash of the locally-made CN-235 aircraft was caused by human error and that there was nothing wrong with the airplane.

President Suharto has said the crash parliamentary course prepared by the State Minister for Special Assignments Harmoko is not compulsory. He said the three political parties, the ruling Golkar, the United Development Party (PPP) and the Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) are free do decide whether to enroll their representatives for the course.

Businessman Probosutedjo, who is also President Suharto's half brother, has said he believed the next vice president would be someone from the military. Suharto is expected to seek a seventh five-year term at the presidential election next year along with a running mate.
